slides.title: Welcome to Renewable Energy
slides.content:
# Introduction to Renewable Energy

Welcome to **Renewable Energy** - power from nature!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Solar Energy** - Power from the sun
- **Wind Energy** - Power from air movement
- **Hydropower** - Power from water
- **Biofuels** - Power from biomass
- **Energy Storage** - Saving energy for later

> **Fun Fact:** Renewable energy supplied 29% of global electricity in 2023!

slides.title: Solar Energy
slides.content:
# Solar Energy

## Photovoltaics (PV):
- Convert sunlight directly to electricity
- Solar cells made of silicon
- Efficiency: 15-22% (commercial)

## Concentrated Solar Power (CSP):
- Mirrors focus sunlight
- Heat drives steam turbine
- Can store thermal energy

## Advantages:
- Abundant, free fuel
- Low operating costs
- Modular and scalable

## Challenges:
- Intermittent (night, clouds)
- Land use
- Manufacturing energy

## Applications:
- Rooftop, utility scale
- Off-grid systems

slides.title: Wind Energy
slides.content:
# Wind Energy

## How It Works:
- Wind turns turbine blades
- Generator converts to electricity

## Turbine Types:
| Type | Axis | Use |
|------|------|-----|
| Horizontal | Horizontal | Most common |
| Vertical | Vertical | Urban |

## Performance:
- Power proportional to wind speed^3
- Capacity factor: 25-45%

## Advantages:
- Clean, no fuel cost
- Competitive price

## Challenges:
- Variable wind
- Visual impact
- Bird/bat impacts
- Noise

## Offshore Wind:
- Stronger, steadier winds
- Higher cost
- Larger turbines

slides.title: Hydropower
slides.content:
# Hydropower

## How It Works:
- Water flows through turbine
- Potential energy -> Kinetic -> Electrical

## Types:

| Type | Description |
|------|-------------|
| Conventional | Dam and reservoir |
| Run-of-river | No large reservoir |
| Pumped storage | Energy storage |
| Tidal | Ocean tides |
| Wave | Ocean waves |

## Advantages:
- Reliable, dispatchable
- Long lifespan
- Low operating cost

## Challenges:
- Ecosystem impacts
- Displacement of people
- Drought vulnerability
- Large upfront cost

slides.title: Bioenergy
slides.content:
# Bioenergy

## Sources:
- Agricultural residues
- Wood and forestry waste
- Energy crops
- Organic waste
- Algae

## Biofuels:

| Type | Source | Use |
|------|--------|-----|
| Ethanol | Corn, sugarcane | Transport fuel |
| Biodiesel | Vegetable oils | Diesel replacement |
| Biogas | Anaerobic digestion | Heat, electricity |

## Advantages:
- Carbon neutral (in theory)
- Uses waste
- Dispatchable

## Challenges:
- Land use competition
- Food vs fuel debate
- Lifecycle emissions

slides.title: Geothermal Energy
slides.content:
# Geothermal Energy

## How It Works:
- Heat from Earth's interior
- Steam drives turbines

## Types:
| Type | Temperature | Use |
|------|-------------|-----|
| High temp | >150 C | Electricity |
| Low temp | <150 C | Direct heat |
| Ground source | Constant | Heat pumps |

## Advantages:
- Constant, reliable
- Small footprint
- Low emissions

## Challenges:
- Location-limited
- Drilling costs
- Induced seismicity (rare)

## Hotspots:
- Iceland, New Zealand
- Philippines, Indonesia

slides.title: Energy Storage
slides.content:
# Energy Storage

## Why Needed:
- Renewables are variable
- Match supply to demand
- Grid stability

## Technologies:

| Type | Duration | Scale |
|------|----------|-------|
| Batteries | Hours | Any |
| Pumped hydro | Hours-days | Large |
| Compressed air | Hours | Large |
| Flywheel | Seconds-min | Medium |
| Hydrogen | Long-term | Any |

## Lithium-ion Batteries:
- Most common
- Declining costs
- EVs and grid scale

## Hydrogen:
- Store as H2 gas
- Long duration
- Green hydrogen from electrolysis

slides.title: Grid Integration
slides.content:
# Grid Integration

## Challenges:
- Variable generation
- Grid stability
- Transmission needs

## Solutions:

| Solution | Purpose |
|----------|--------|
| Storage | Smooth variability |
| Demand response | Shift consumption |
| Smart grids | Better control |
| Interconnection | Share resources |
| Forecasting | Predict generation |

## Capacity Factor:
- Actual vs maximum output
- Solar: ~15-25%
- Wind: ~25-45%
- Hydro: ~30-60%

## Duck Curve:
- Solar creates midday surplus
- Evening ramp needed

slides.title: Economics
slides.content:
# Renewable Energy Economics

## Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE):
- Total cost / lifetime energy
- Renewables now competitive

## Cost Trends:
| Source | Change since 2010 |
|--------|------------------|
| Solar PV | -90% |
| Onshore wind | -70% |
| Batteries | -90% |

## Incentives:
- Feed-in tariffs
- Tax credits
- Renewable portfolio standards
- Carbon pricing

## Jobs:
- 12+ million globally
- Growing sector

slides.title: Future of Renewables
slides.content:
# Future Outlook

## Growth Projections:
- Renewables to dominate by 2050
- Solar fastest growing
- Wind second fastest

## Emerging Technologies:
- Floating offshore wind
- Perovskite solar cells
- Green hydrogen
- Ocean thermal
- Advanced geothermal

## Net Zero Goals:
- Paris Agreement targets
- Many countries 2050 net zero
- Electrification of everything

## Challenges Remaining:
- Seasonal storage
- Hard-to-decarbonize sectors
- Developing world access

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Renewable Energy Summary

## Sources:
| Source | Key Feature |
|--------|------------|
| Solar | Most abundant |
| Wind | Cost competitive |
| Hydro | Reliable, storage |
| Geothermal | Constant |
| Bioenergy | Dispatchable |

## Storage:
- Batteries, pumped hydro
- Hydrogen for long-term

## Economics:
- Costs dropping rapidly
- Now cheapest in many regions

## Future:
- Growing share of energy
- Key to climate goals
